content: Joan <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan>’s novel, recently adapted into a miniseries, was the first in the “gone girl” <span class="word-wrap-span">genrespan> ![Why “Picnic at Hanging Rock” is an alluring Antipodean classic](https://cdn.static-economist.com/sites/default/files/20180818_BKP502.jpg) THE STORY came to Joan <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan> in a dream in 1966. She had holidayed at Hanging Rock as a child. The vivid and disturbing vision recurred for two weeks; she shut the door to her study and wrote it down, <span class="word-wrap-span">feverishlyspan>, through a cold winter. “Picnic at Hanging Rock” was released the following year, <span class="word-wrap-span">republishspan>ed by Penguin in 1975 and <span class="word-wrap-span">reissuespan>d this year by Penguin <span class="word-wrap-span">Classicspan>s. The <span class="word-wrap-span">cultspan> novel—the first in a thriving <span class="word-wrap-span">genrespan> of “gone girls”—continues to <span class="word-wrap-span">beguilespan>: it has been adapted into a new six-part miniseries. Framed as a true story, the tale begins on <span class="word-wrap-span">Valentinespan>’s Day in 1900 on the “well-trimmed <span class="word-wrap-span">lawnspan>s” of Appleyard College, an <span class="word-wrap-span">exclusivespan> girls’ school <span class="word-wrap-span">nestlespan>d in the Australian bush outside <span class="word-wrap-span">Melbournespan>. The students are preparing for an <span class="word-wrap-span">educationalspan> trip to observe the <span class="word-wrap-span">geologyspan> of Mount <span class="word-wrap-span">Diogenesspan>—or “Hanging Rock”—a former volcano. As their horse and <span class="word-wrap-span">carriagespan> departs, Mrs Appleyard, the school’s steely <span class="word-wrap-span">headmistressspan>, urges them to <span class="word-wrap-span">bewarespan> the dangers of the area. “The vicinity is <span class="word-wrap-span">renownspan>ed for its venomous snakes and <span class="word-wrap-span">poisonousspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">antspan>s,” she cautions. She has no idea, yet, that more menacing, <span class="word-wrap-span">intangiblespan> threats will cause the disappearance of four members of the party. The moment of their vanishing is <span class="word-wrap-span">elidespan>d; as the hour draws near for the group’s return no trace of them can be found. Search teams are sent out and <span class="word-wrap-span">Aboriginalspan> trackers <span class="word-wrap-span">enlistspan>ed. <span class="word-wrap-span">Mirandaspan>, <span class="word-wrap-span">Marionspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">Irmaspan>—who ventured up into the rock on that fateful day, along with their teacher <span class="word-wrap-span">Gretaspan> McGraw—have gone. <span class="word-wrap-span">Scrapspan>s of torn material lead to the <span class="word-wrap-span">eventualspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">discoveryspan> of <span class="word-wrap-span">Irmaspan>, <span class="word-wrap-span">dehydratespan>d, <span class="word-wrap-span">confusespan>d but unharmed, who has no <span class="word-wrap-span">recollectionspan> of the events. The others are never discovered. “Picnic at Hanging Rock” is a rare novel that refuses to provide a <span class="word-wrap-span">resolutionspan> to its central question (though after <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan>’s death, and following <span class="word-wrap-span">intensespan> public demand, a last chapter—better <span class="word-wrap-span">omittedspan>, said her <span class="word-wrap-span">cannyspan> editor in the 1960s—was released in 1987.) It was <span class="word-wrap-span">Patriciaspan> Lovell, a producer, who first thought that the dark subject matter and <span class="word-wrap-span">otherworldlyspan> natural landscape would work well on the big screen, and approached <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan> for the rights. In 1975 the film was shot on <span class="word-wrap-span">locationspan>. Director Peter <span class="word-wrap-span">Weirspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">honespan>d in on the <span class="word-wrap-span">sinisterspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">ambivalencespan> of this ancient rock amid the <span class="word-wrap-span">lushspan> southern-Australian landscape; to capture the slow-moving, <span class="word-wrap-span">saturatespan>d quality of the text, Mr <span class="word-wrap-span">Weirspan> approached Henri <span class="word-wrap-span">Cartierspan>-Bresson, a French <span class="word-wrap-span">photojournalistspan> known as a <span class="word-wrap-span">masterspan> of “<span class="word-wrap-span">candidspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">photographyspan>”, for advice. The camera was <span class="word-wrap-span">drapespan>d in a thin sheet of <span class="word-wrap-span">bridalspan>-veil <span class="word-wrap-span">fabricspan>, which created an effect visually stunning in its softness. The film was widely praised for allowing the story to unfold in a <span class="word-wrap-span">nuancespan>d, <span class="word-wrap-span">hypnoticspan> manner. The new <span class="word-wrap-span">adaptationspan> departs from the gentle, <span class="word-wrap-span">hallucinatoryspan> tone of the film but poses fresh questions raised by <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan>’s text. It spans six hours, so viewers are given (no spoilers) more answers than would be possible in a feature film. It takes a deeper dive into the <span class="word-wrap-span">psychologyspan> of the characters, both before and after the disappearance. The criminal history of Mrs Appleyard—a <span class="word-wrap-span">departurespan> from the text but a <span class="word-wrap-span">shrewdspan> one—is well <span class="word-wrap-span">evokespan>d by a cool <span class="word-wrap-span">Nataliespan> <span class="word-wrap-span">Dormerspan>. The impact of the incident on the remaining teenagers, vulnerable and struggling to make sense of the <span class="word-wrap-span">incomprehensiblespan>, is slowly <span class="word-wrap-span">revealspan>ed. The <span class="word-wrap-span">claustrophobicspan> atmosphere is similar to that in “The <span class="word-wrap-span">Cruciblespan>”. This new <span class="word-wrap-span">iterationspan> of “Picnic at Hanging Rock” offers a <span class="word-wrap-span">sharpenspan>ed focus on female friendship and desire, but is most compelling in its approach to the book’s <span class="word-wrap-span">colonialspan> subtext. The show’s <span class="word-wrap-span">depictionspan>s of <span class="word-wrap-span">lavishspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">Victorianspan> wealth are set alongside an ugly past the characters <span class="word-wrap-span">overlookspan>. Mount <span class="word-wrap-span">Diogenesspan> was occupied by <span class="word-wrap-span">indigenousspan> tribes for thousands of years before British settlers forced these groups from the land; it is Appleyard College that <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan> describes as “an <span class="word-wrap-span">architecturalspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">anachronismspan> in the Australian bush – a <span class="word-wrap-span">hopelessspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">misfitspan> in time and space”. One of the scenes in the novel takes place at the garden party of a wealthy family; in the series, toasts are raised to the “united colonies” of Queen Victoria. Even within this “united” space clear divisions of class, race and gender <span class="word-wrap-span">aboundspan>. Those divisions are made more signific<span class="word-wrap-span">antspan> by the casting of <span class="word-wrap-span">Madeleinespan> <span class="word-wrap-span">Maddenspan>, an <span class="word-wrap-span">indigenousspan> actress, as <span class="word-wrap-span">Marionspan> (pictured). “I wonder if <span class="word-wrap-span">Marionspan>’s more recent <span class="word-wrap-span">representationspan> is me<span class="word-wrap-span">antspan> to <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan> the ‘Stolen Generations,’” says <span class="word-wrap-span">Rosemariespan> Miller, an <span class="word-wrap-span">associatespan> <span class="word-wrap-span">lecturerspan> at the University of <span class="word-wrap-span">Worcesterspan>, referring to the children of Australian <span class="word-wrap-span">Aboriginalspan> and <span class="word-wrap-span">Torresspan> Strait Islanders who were <span class="word-wrap-span">forciblyspan> removed from their families and placed in government institutions from 1905 until around 1967. It gives the missing-child <span class="word-wrap-span">narrativespan> at the story’s heart a <span class="word-wrap-span">revisionistspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">poignancyspan> that speaks to the present day. “In <span class="word-wrap-span">contemporaryspan> times, when children are separated from parents during border crossings, or filmed in war zones…society’s failure to protect <span class="word-wrap-span">revealspan>s that the <span class="word-wrap-span">Gothicspan> lies more within <span class="word-wrap-span">cultspan>ure than wild nature,” she says. In 2008 when Kevin Rudd, then Australia’s prime minister, issued an apology to the victims of the separations on behalf of the country’s <span class="word-wrap-span">parliamentspan>, many had died and so were unable to accept or reject the <span class="word-wrap-span">acknowledgespan>ment of wrongdoing. Their disappearance, and the lack of answers offered after so many years, was a disturbing reality with no <span class="word-wrap-span">neatspan> conclusion. <span class="word-wrap-span">Lindsayspan>’s tale <span class="word-wrap-span">derivespan>s its power from its own rejection of a <span class="word-wrap-span">resolutionspan>. It defies the old <span class="word-wrap-span">adagespan> that the <span class="word-wrap-span">simplestspan> explanation is often the correct one, and will continue to haunt readers for generations to come.
